ygData.subject: Re: FloatFastConcurrentNetwork - Performance Optimization
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Thomas, I certainly recognize the relevance of Linux in research.  In fact, most of my recent experiments are run on Linux clusters, so breaking Mono

Hi Thomas,

I certainly recognize the relevance of Linux in research.  In f=
act, most of my recent experiments are run on Linux clusters, so breaking M=
ono compatibility isn't really an option (although with the new features in=
 .NET 4.0, it is tempting).  Most of the time I compile in Windows and run =
in Linux, but compiling and running HyperSharpNEAT in Linux shouldn't be to=
o hard.  With Ubuntu 9.10 you should be able to just do the following:

1. =
 Install the latest Mono runtime and MonoDevelop from the package manger.

=
2.  Run MonoDevelop and choose to open the HyperSharpNEAT.sln file in the s=
rc directory.

3.  The solution should now be imported, and you should be a=
ble to build and run the projects.  For example you can right click the Ski=
rmishVisualization project and select "Set as startup project" then right c=
lick the solution and click "Run item" and it should pop up a new window wi=
th a zero in the upper left corner.

If you want to do things strictly from=
 from the command line, I don't have much experience there, but I can look =
into it for you.  Thanks for pointing out that my current Linux build instr=
uctions are somewhat lacking, I'll add this more detailed set to the next r=
elease. If you have any problems, don't hesitate to email me.

Thanks,
Davi=
d D'Ambrosio
ddambro@...

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Thomas John=
son <thomas.j.johnson@...> wrote:
>
> As long as you guys are talking about=
 integrating new code, can I request
> that someone includes a step-by-step=
 of how to build on a modern Linux
> system with mono? A lot of scientific =
computing takes place on Linux these
> days, but the HyperNEAT C++ code is =
very difficult to build due to the way
> the CMake configuration is set up =
and the weird dependencies (TinyXMLDLL?!).
> The HyperSharpNEAT code is muc=
h better, but it's not clear to me how to
> build it on Linux.
> 
> On Sun,=
 Nov 29, 2009 at 7:18 AM, Colin Green <colin.green1@...>wrote:
> 
> >
> >
>=
 > Hi,
> >
> > Yeh the SN2 code is essentially a complete re-write with a p=
rimary
> > goal being a more flexible, general-purpose EC framework. There =
were
> > perhaps some forgotten corners in SN1 and this is addressed by the=

> > re-write. Now that the core code is settled I've been re-reviewing it
=
> > all as a whole before progressing further, fixing the odd bug,
> > refa=
ctoring a few sections that were tagged with FIXMEs, TODOs, and
> > ENHANCE=
MENTs (some of these remain as they are low priority) and
> > ensuring the =
comments (XML and in-line) are meaningful.
> >
> > Performance in SN1 was a=
 primary design goal and is pretty good I
> > think. I ran it through a pro=
filer and homed in and rewrote some of
> > the less efficient sections - ne=
ural net decoding and activation being
> > the main areas I can recall, oh =
and genome comparison was sped up 100x
> > or so at one point. SN2 hasn't b=
een through a profiler yet but I've
> > been writing pretty tight code IMO =
and taking lessons and code from
> > SN1. Even so it always pays to run cod=
e through a profiler in case
> > something has been missed or some unintend=
ed things are going on - new
> > thinsg like k-means algorithm migth need e=
xtra work (e.g.
> > multithreading).
> >
> > There probably are a few point=
s where events would make sense and this
> > is something that can be layer=
ed on now that the core code is settled,
> > however, events in high freque=
ncy code such as mutations could hit
> > performance so care should be take=
n. My main aim here is to get the
> > core stuff right, others can then tak=
e the code and bend it to their
> > particular needs.
> >
> > FxCop I have =
used briefly. IMO the default checks aren't quite aligned
> > to what I'm t=
rying to achieve, that is, I'm not aiming for a
> > fixed/pre-compiled API =
for commercial use by the masses. There's also
> > some degree of personal =
opinion on what checks to make - I personally
> > disagree with /some/ of t=
he default checks, but its worth taking a
> > fresh look at and maybe tweak=
ing some of the rules.
> >
> > If you have any more thoughts on the SN2 cod=
e then let me know, IMO
> > releasing source code into the wild is how good=
 quality code gets
> > written, the more pairs of eyes the better, and at t=
he end of the day
> > if people disagree strongly with the direction it's g=
oing then it's
> > open source.
> >
> > Hope that all makes sense,
> >
> > =
Colin
> >  
> >
>
